'''Frugalware Linux''' is a general-purpose [[Linux distribution]] designed for intermediate users who are familiar with command-line operations. Early versions were based on [[Slackware]], but it is now an independently-developed distribution. Frugalware uses the [[Pacman (package manager)|Pacman]] [[package management system]].<ref name="openaddict-interview">{{cite web| title=Interview with Frugalware Linux Developer, VMiklos | publisher=Open Addict | url=http://www.openaddict.com/interview_with_frugalware_linux_developer_vmiklos.html | accessdate =2008-02-27 | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070714171605/http://www.openaddict.com/interview_with_frugalware_linux_developer_vmiklos.html | archivedate =2007-07-14 }}</ref>
== Aims == Frugalware's developers attempt to make Frugalware as simple as possible while establishing a priority based on comfortable use. Their goal is to ship consistently fresh and stable software, as close to the original source as possible.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}
== History == Frugalware was founded in 2004 by MiklÃ³s Vajna. He considered Slackware's [[Package management system|package manager]] ''pkgtools'' too slow, and wanted to rewrite it in [[C (programming language)|C]]. He was told that it would never be accepted by Slackware, so Vajna started to think about founding a separate Linux distribution. He replaced Slackware's original package manager, [[init]] scripts and build system. As a result, Frugalware was born.<ref name="distrowatch-vmiklos">{{cite web| title=Interview with MiklÃ³s Vajna, Frugalware Linux | publisher=[[DistroWatch]] | url=http://distrowatch.com/weekly.php?issue=20060522#interview | accessdate =2008-03-26 }}</ref>
== Package management == Since version 0.6 Frugalware has used Pacman-G2 package manager.<ref name="terminus-changelog">{{cite web| title=Frugalware 0.6 (Terminus) Changelog| publisher=Frugalware Project | url=http://ftp.frugalware.org/pub/archive/frugalware-0.6/ChangeLog.txt | format=TXT | accessdate =2008-02-27}}</ref> It is a fork of a CVS version of the complete rewrite of [[Pacman (package manager)|Pacman]] by Aurelien Foret, which was not officially released at the time.<ref name="pacman-g2">{{cite web| title=Pacman-G2| work=Frugalware Stable Documentation | publisher=Frugalware Project | url=http://frugalware.org/docs/stable/pacman-g2.html | accessdate =2008-10-14}}</ref> Previously Frugalware used a modified version of the older, monolithic Pacman by Judd Vinet.
Frugalware's packages' extension is .fpm.<ref name="makepkg">{{cite web| title=Creating new packages| work=Frugalware Stable Documentation | publisher=Frugalware Project | url=http://frugalware.org/docs/stable/makepkg.html | accessdate =2008-10-14}}</ref> The packages are archives that are compressed using [[xz]].<ref name="about">{{cite web| title=About Frugalware| work=Frugalware Stable Documentation | publisher=Frugalware Project | url=http://frugalware.org/docs/stable/about.html | accessdate =2011-09-11}}</ref>
Repoman is a tool to compile source packages and automatically create and install closed-source packages.<ref name="0.3pre1"/> With Repoman, the user can also download all packages' buildscript and recompile them with specific build options. The build options can be changed by editing a configuration file.<ref name="makepkg"/> The first Frugalware release that had Repoman was Frugalware 0.3pre1.<ref name="0.3pre1">{{cite web| title=Frugalware 0.3pre1-i686 released | accessdate =2008-02-27 | publisher=Frugalware Project | url=http://frugalware.org/news/22 }}</ref>
== Branches == Frugalware has a -current and a -stable branch. The -current branch is updated daily, and the -stable branch gets updated every 6 months.<ref name="about"/>
== Architectures == Frugalware currently supports x86 (Pentium Pro or higher), x86_64 (k8, aka. amd64) platforms and ppc (PowerPC)<ref name="about"/>.
